results.title: Two lives
results.creator_credit: Duc Hoang Nguyen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Duc Hoang Nguyen remembers the bitter past of life in Vietnam during the war and a new found life of peace and freedom in Australia.

results.title: A Journey to freedom
results.creator_credit: Gia Binh Lieu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Escaping from Vietnam in 1988 to look for freedom, Gia Binh Lieu became a refugee and settled in Australia. His story is of family and disconnection, of survival and a better future.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gia Binh Lieu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.brief_description: Eleven digital stories of family separation, war and conflict, escape and new beginnings, created by a group of Vietnamese men who participated in the Mens Line Workshop held in Sydney from 5-8 November 2007.

results.title: Two hours of christmas cartoons
results.creator_credit: Hughes Leisure Group and Music World
results.brief_description: A compilation of cartoons from the forties and fifties which feature classic stories such as ‘Rudolph the red-nosed reindeer’, ‘Santa’s surprise’, ‘Jingle bell foolin’, ‘Christmas circus’ and a host of other titles guaranteed to generate lots of Christmas spirit.

results.title: Two hands [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Gregor Jordan, Marian MacGowan, CML and Meridian Films
results.brief_description: Set in Sydney’s King’s Cross, 19 year old Jimmy (Heath Ledger) finds himself in debt to a local gangster, Pando, played by perennial Australian actor Bryan Brown, when a simple job goes wrong. Jimmy’s life depends on his locating the $10,000 he has lost. As his scheme to replace the cash is played out, two street kids are enjoying a shopping spree with the original loot. The black humour of the film progressively darkens as the story unfolds. Rose Byrne co-stars as country girl, Alex, who becomes involved with Jimmy and his increasingly dire situation.

results.title: Thee Films: 1950's - 1960's
results.creator_credit: Antony Balch, William S. Burroughs and Psychic Television
results.brief_description: Five short films featuring the poetry and prose of the Beat writers; William Burroughs, Brion Gyson and Ian Somerville. Filmed in New York City, Paris and Tangiers, the films do not use narrative but rather incorporate avant-garde and experimental film techniques. Burroughs’ poetry, and his commitment to homo-eroticism and heroin use, feature prominently in the films. “William buys a parrot”, “The cut-ups” and “Bill and Tony” last a few minutes whilst “Towers open fire” and “Ghosts at no. 9 (Paris)” are longer films. The last film is an hour excerpt of a longer five hour epic.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Antony Balch, William S. Burroughs and Psychic Television

results.title: What's wrong with this picture?
results.creator_credit: Sonia Whiteman and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Shot in 16mm and VHS, this film is reminiscent of the silent era. The main character, a young man, lives in a world filled with paradoxes; he drives through a shopping mall, walks backwards and reads newspapers upside down. The title recalls the children’s game of trying to pick the fault in an image; this experimental film, shot in black and white, encourages the spectator to do the same. A beautiful musical score by Barry Adamson.

results.title: What's under the label
results.creator_credit: Ronald Weyman, Donald Mulholland and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Precautions taken to safeguard the food and drugs sold in Canada. This film is the story of how Canada’s pure food and drug laws are enforced - the checking of food in retail stores, testing in Government laboratories, and destruction of faulty products. With new foods and drugs coming on the market daily, the film points out that constant vigilance is essential for the protection of the Canadian consumer.
